section.name: Directory Structure
section.p: Dalma container has the following directory structure
section.source: dalmacon/ (directory pointed by $DALMA_HOME) +- bin/ +- lib/ +- apps/ | +- *.dar | +- <app>/ | +- *.jar | +- <class files> +- modules/ | +- <module>/ | +- *.jar +- conf/ | +- <app>.properties +- work/ +- <app>/ +- data

subsection.name: bin/
subsection.p: This directory has the shell script / batch file to launch dalma container, as well as jar files that constitute core container code. These jar files are loaded through the Class-Path entry in META-INF/MANIFEST.MF, so you can't place additional jars in this directory.

subsection.name: lib/
subsection.p: Any jar file placed in this directory are made visible to the applications that run in the container. This directory can be used to place common jar files that can be shared among applications.

subsection.name: apps/
subsection.p: This directory hosts workflow applications. Applications can be placed as individual directories that contain jar files or class files directly (that is, you can have jar files like apps/myapp/abc.jar, and/or class files like apps/myapp/org/acme/Foo.class). The directory name becomes the workflow application name. Each application is loaded by a separate class loader for isolation.
Alternatively, a workflow application can be packaged into a dalma archive (*.dar) and placed directly in the apps/ directory.

subsection.name: modules/
subsection.p: This directory hosts additional endpoint implementations. Each module is placed in their own individual directory, but note that all the jar files and class files are loaded by the same classloader. Individual directories are only to make module development/deployment easier.

subsection.name: conf/
subsection.p: This directory hosts configuration files for each workflow application (in <appname>.properties) as well as a configuration file for the container itself (dalma.properties).

subsection.name: work/
subsection.p: The container uses this directory to store various information about the running applications. In particular, it included the persisted conversation state.
